thread.title: 2015 girls volleyball | Princess Anne looking for title
thread.title_full: 2015 girls volleyball preview | Princess Anne looking for title | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Ray Nimmo
title: 2015 girls volleyball | Princess Anne looking for title
text:
THINGS TO KNOW YOUTH SERVES
An above-average number of girls teams lost several seniors and are counting on underclassmen. Several of the area’s best players are juniors, including Princess Anne’s Alyssa Presto and Ocean Lakes’ Danielle Hart. There are also high expectations for a pair of incoming freshman: Jayna Francis (Princess Anne) and Gracie Johnson (Cox).
STATE TITLE HUNTING
The Princess Anne girls team has had its rough share of defeats through the years, whether in the former Beach District semifinals or in last season’s state final. Persistence usually pays and the Cavaliers should have two great chances at a Group 5A title the next two years as they’re led by a stellar junior class. Ocean Lakes also has a state runner-up finish in recent memory and the Dolphins are capable of a deep run.
___
TOP 10 TEAMS IN SOUTH HAMPTON ROADS
1. Princess Anne
Coming within one point of winning the Group 5A state title was crushing, but the Cavaliers return revitalized. Gone is All-Tidewater Player of the Year Alex Toben, so expect a more diverse attack. Setter Alyssa Presto will build her offense around Abby Bottomley, Chika Osuchukwu, Ashley Burgess and Julia Rochester. But keep an eye on freshman Jayna Francis. Already 5-foot-11, Francis’ power may allow another hitter to fall back to a much-needed defensive hole left by All-Tidewater libero Margaret Latchford, now at Liberty. After that state final loss, coach Craig Dooren vowed to find that one missing point in the offseason. Weeks ahead of the new season, he said, “I sure hope we found it.”
2. Ocean Lakes
Standing at 6-4, junior middle Danielle Hart, is a sky-high presence. But the Dolphins aren’t a one-trick pony. Always well-rounded, they welcome back setter Alisi Motu’apuaka, outsides Liv Crawley and Taylor Allbritten, middle Lauren Zell, opposite LeeAnne Dean and libero Kelly Smith. “I am quite confident that when we hit on all cylinders it will be fun to watch,” coach Jack Wheeler said. To combat complacency, Wheeler has introduced new drills in practices, while players have been mixing up practice partners to break routine.
3. Kellam
Taking a backseat to First Colonial and Princess Anne may not be ideal for the proud program, but the Knights still hang around. All-Tidewater outside Reilly King graduated and the Knights will rely on returning role players who face the new pressure of starting minutes. Junior libero Savannah Marshall and sophomore middle Tori Morris are back. “Any given day, any one of many players could be the star,” co-head coach Janice Johnson said.
4. Cox
Senior outside Ashlee Jaworsky and senior setter Taylor Dunn hope to lead Cox to its potential. The Falcons have shown flashes the past couple years under coach Jason Zuidema, Cox’s longtime boys coach who pulls double duty. Freshman Gracie Johnson enters the fold and should see plenty of time to make an impression. Zuidema said Johnson is “easily the best freshman volleyball player to come through in a while.”
5. First Colonial
Winning the 6A title in a mind-numbing 25-23 fifth set is impossible to top. Nevertheless, the Patriots press on with senior outside Rowan Ennis. She is joined by sophomore setter Brie Severino, the only other returning starter. Seven seniors graduated, including former All-Tidewater Player of the Year Catie Espinoza. While the team’s return from volleyball’s summit may be a struggle early, don’t count out FC in the postseason.
6. Nansemond-Suffolk
The defending VISAA Division II state champion lost five senior starters and the new crop will be looking up at the competition. No player stands taller than 5-8, so expect a different style from the Saints. Four juniors – hitters Livi Bono, Logan Harrell and Lindsay Knierbein and setter Nicole Wright – played club ball together and their chemistry is key to success.
7. Grassfield
The Monitor-Merrimac Conference defending champion is led by St. Francis (Pa.) commit Cecelia Pisano, a senior libero/setter. The Grizzlies have long been a tough program under coach Robin Smith and this year should be no different. Clashes with Western Branch and new conference foe Granby should be great. Sophomores Jailee Johnson and Taylor Didawick will provide offense on the pins.
8. Hickory
Lone returning starter Erin Parks, a senior outside, guides the Hawks into a rebuilding year. A traditional Chesapeake power, Hickory should remain competitive behind Parks and fellow seniors Maddie Hughley, who takes over setting duties, and outside Natalie Eaton.
9. Salem
Expect the SunDevils to contend following years of an also-ran moniker. Salem’s junior class is awash with club experience, led by 6-foot outside Quiana Griffin. “They’re coming back with a vengeance,” coach Kelly Mills said. Juniors Lindsey Taylor, Sammy Sabater, Anaya Ghacham and SaTyna Jamison join Griffin.
10. Bayside
With senior libero Briana Kerr and sophomore middle Megan Sivertson, the Marlins are poised for a successful year, despite being in one of the state’s most brutal conferences. “Ninety-percent of our roster has club experience,” coach Butch Caldwell said.
___
FIVE PLAYERS TO KNOW
Abby Bottomley, Princess Anne: “Abby is one of the best all-around players in the state,” coach Craig Dooren said.
Rowan Ennis, First Colonial: A fierce attacker, Ennis, committed to UC Santa Barbara, becomes the heart and soul of FC’s offense.
Danielle Hart, Ocean Lakes: The skillful junior middle has already committed to Virginia Tech.
Ashlee Jaworsky, Cox: At 5-10, the outside hitter is the “offensive threat at the pin,” coach Jason Zuidema said.
Alyssa Presto, Princess Anne: The junior has maintained status as one of the area’s best setters since starting freshman year.
___
ELSEWHERE
In Group 6A ...
Granby ’s lineup may include five sophomores, particularly Hannah Talliere and Megan Baxter. Senior Miranda Cooksey will also help. ... Great Bridge coach Stephanie Puett expects “a fun season to watch” with Christina Booth, Giorgia Maciel and Tyla Player. ... Landstown is loaded with freshmen and sophomores, including outsides Becca Hooser and Megan McGuire. ... Oscar Smith graduated five starters but senior middle Kylie Jacobs and senior outside Charolette Housand return. ... Western Branch returns All-Conference picks Peyton Holmes and Audra Wendell and adds a Florida transfer in libero Jazmine Collins.
___
In Group 5A ...
Juniors Michaela Proffitt and Kayla Gates head an Indian River team moving into the tough Atlantic Conference. ... Meghan Toy, Chaniyah Watson, Ebryana Green and Jackie Martin return for Green Run .
___
Group 4A
Langley Ungaro, Colleen Merullo and Rebecca Snipes lead a young Churchland squad in Conference 17.
___
In private schools ...
Abigail Finn, Skylar Johnson, Kennedy Beale and Hazael Tankard lead Cape Henry , which is still looking for a setter after the graduation of All-Tidewater pick Gabby Goodall. ... Judi Dunham takes over as Greenbrier Christian ’s coach. ... 6-foot-3 middle Hannah Barcus and senior Megan Monroe lead Norfolk Academy ’s offense along with setter Casey Mahan and libero Lena Hinkle. ... Norfolk Collegiate, led by outside Bailey Jones, may bring up two eighth-graders for setting duties. ... Captains Allie Plumlee, a junior outside, and Aradhana Khubani, a senior setter, are StoneBridge School ’s go-to players for another run at the Metro Conference title.
___
RECLASSIFICATION
Another round of realignment by the Virginia High School League has shuffled area teams for the 2015-16 school year. For the first time, Hampton Roads public schools will be spread across four classifications – Group 6A, Group 5A, Group 4A and Group 3A.
Four teams move down in classification: Booker T. Washington, Norcom, Lakeland and Phoebus all move to Group 3A, while Great Bridge heads to Group 4A.
Kellam, meanwhile, has moved up to Group 6A and Nansemond River to Group 5A.
A look at the new conference alignment:
Group 6A
Coastal Conference: Bayside, Cox, First Colonial, Kellam, Landstown, Ocean Lakes, Tallwood.
Monitor-Merrimac Conference: Granby, Grassfield, Oscar Smith, Western Branch, Woodside.
___
Group 5A
Atlantic Conference: Green Run, Hickory, Indian River, Kempsville, Maury, Norview, Princess Anne, Salem.
PenSouth Conference: Bethel, Gloucester, Hampton, Kecoughtan, Menchville, Nansemond River, Warwick.
___
Group 4A
Conference 17: Churchland, Deep Creek, Great Bridge, King’s Fork, Lake Taylor, Wilson.
Ironclad Conference: Denbigh, Grafton, Heritage, Jamestown, Lafayette, Smithfield.
___
Group 3A
Conference 27: Booker T. Washington, Lakeland, Norcom, Phoebus, Tabb, York.
___
Ray Nimmo, 757-446-2364 or ray.nimmo@pilotonline.com; Twitter: @Ray_Nimmo
